pasuk.text: It all follows the order, i.e., Moses gave over the Torah to Joshua, and Joshua to the Elders, and each judge to his successor, until it reached Eli, by whom it was given over to Samuel, as we learned in the Mishnah (Avoth 1:1): and the Elders gave it over to the Prophets.
There were two hills, each visible to the other. (Meg. 14a) Jonathan, however, renders ‘Zophim’ of the disciples of the Prophets.
Elkanah was a Levite of the sons of Ebiasaf the son of Korah. Thus his ancestry is recorded in Chron. (I, 6:7 12).

Jonathan renders: on the mountain of the House of Ephraim. Midrash Aggadah (M.S. 1:16): Ephrathi, a palace dweller, a nobleman, an important person, like (the Talmudic word ‘aperion’, used in B.M. 119a): Let us extend ‘aperion’ to Rabbi Simon. An expression of favor.

text.title: And that man was wont to go up:

pasuk.text: This is the present tense. He would go up from one appointed season to another appointed season, to Shiloh. Midrash Aggadah (M.S. 1: 1,5, 7): The route he followed this year he did not follow the next year, in order to publicize (his pilgrimage) to the Israelites that they should do likewise.

text.title: And when it was the day:

pasuk.text: And it was the festive day.[after Jonathan].
one choice portion: a portion which is fit to be accepted with a friendly countenance.
Her husband’s other wife, Peninnah.
Anger after anger, always. Therefore, it is written: ‘also anger.’ She would say to her, “Did you buy your older son a cloak today, or your younger son a shirt?”

text.title: in order to make her complain::

pasuk.text: (Literally, to make her storm.) Our rabbis explain, “in order to make her storm” that she pray. And Peninnah had good intentions.
Lit., opposite her womb, and so is every expression of the word בעד.
I. e., Elkanah.
He would give her a choice portion to demonstrate to her that he loved her and her rival would anger her more and more according to the affection which her husband demonstrated to her.
Don’t I love you more dearly…
that Peninnah has borne to me?

(אכלה). The הא is not dotted and the אלף is voweled with a short קמץ, and it is like אחרי אכול, meaning after eating in Shiloh and after drinking, and this expression is properly used both for masculine and feminine.
‘After eating’ is a gerund. It is constructed like לאכלה (Lev. 25:6) to eat, an expression equivalent to לאכול an infinitive.

text.title: and Eli the priest was sitting on the chair::

pasuk.text: The defective spelling denotes that on that day, he was seated on a huge chair, for he was appointed judge over Israel.
lit. on the doorpost.

Why was this Name designated here? (The answer is as follows:) She said before Him: O Lord of the universe, You created two hosts in Your world. The heavenly beings do not multiply, neither do they die, while the earthly beings both multiply and die. If I am of the earthly beings let me multiply, and if I am of the heavenly beings let me not die. I found this explanation in the Aggadah of Rabbi Jose the Galilean. Our sages in tractate Ber. (31b), however, expounded what they expounded: Until then there was no person who called the Holy One, blessed be He, “Hosts.” (Why then, did Hannah call Him by this Name?) But, so said she before Him: “O Lord of the universe, from all the hosts which You created in Your world, do You find it difficult to grant me one son?”
(Lit., if seeing You will see.) In tractate Ber., our sages expounded what they expounded.
which is stated three times in this verse, corresponds to the three precepts which a woman is commanded to observe.
(Lit., seed of men, meaning) righteous men, as it is written (Kings I:2:32): “Upon two righteous men.” אנשים also means important men, as it is written (Deut. 1:13): wise and known men.

text.title: and I shall give him to the Lord::

pasuk.text: that he be fit to be given to the Lord.

text.title: and no razor shall come upon his head::

pasuk.text: (translation follows K, however,) Jonathan renders: and the fear of man will not be upon him.
He waited for her to stop. Jonathan renders thus: and Eli waited for her until she stopped.
an expression of waiting, as in (Gen. 37:11) “and his father awaited the thing,” and (Job 14:16) “You do not wait for my sin.”

text.title: and Eli thought her to be a drunken woman::

pasuk.text: for they were not accustomed to praying silently.
You are not a lord in this instance. You yourself have revealed that the holy spirit is not resting upon you, otherwise you would know that I am not intoxicated from wine.

text.title: I am a woman of sorrowful spirit::

pasuk.text: like Sarah (who was childless) [old editions of Rashi].
Considering the fact that she spoke harshly to him, she returned to appease him so that he deliver her not, unprotected and disgraced, at the mercy of her rival, the unscrupulous woman.

text.title: for out of the abundance of my complaint::

pasuk.text: have I spoken harshly before you.

(lit., my speech.) In some instances, it is an expression of grief of heart. Another explanation is, according to the Targum, as follows: for out of the abundance of my provocation and my vexation, have I prolonged my prayer until now.
which my rival vexes me.
(Lit. do not give.) An expression of delivery, like, “deliver me not unto the will of my adversaries” (Ps. 27:12).
(שלתך, instead of שאלתך). The ‘alef’ is missing to expound in this word an expression of ‘children,’ as in Deut. 28:57: ובשליתה “and against her young, which came out, etc.”
He announced to her that her prayer had been accepted.
to beg mercy for her.

text.title: and her face was not (sad) anymore::

pasuk.text: (Lit., and she no longer had her face, meaning) the face of anger.

text.title: and came to their house, and Elkanah knew::

pasuk.text: From here is deduced that a traveler is forbidden to have marital relations.

(After the seasons and the days.) The minimum of seasons is two and the minimum of days is also two. Hence, she gave birth after six months and two days. From here it is deduced that a woman who gives birth after seven months, can give birth after a fraction of the seventh month of pregnancy.
El after the name of God, and in reference to the incident, he was so called, for I asked him of the Lord.
of the appointed seasons.
The vows which he made between pilgrimage festivals, he would sacrifice on the following festival.
after twenty two months (other versions, twenty four), for that is the time of nursing a child.

“Forever” in the Levitic sense means fifty years, as it says, (Num. 8:25), “and from the age of fifty years he shall return from the host of the work.” Figuring as follows, we determine that Samuel’s lifetime was fifty-two years. Eli judged Israel for forty years (see 4:18), and on the day of Hannah’s prayer, he was appointed judge (See above v. 9). By subtracting the year in which Hannah conceived Samuel, there remain thirty nine years. Samuel governed Israel from the time of Eli’s death for thirteen years, figuring thus: On the day of Eli’s death, the Ark was abducted, and it remained in the field of the Philistines for seven months (below 6:1). From there, it was brought to Kiriath-jearim, where it remained until David took it out of there after he had reigned seven years in Hebron over Judah, and all Israel had accepted him as their king. And it is written: And is was, from the day that the Ark abode in Kiriath-jearim that the time was long, for it was twenty years, etc. (below 7:2). Subtract from them seven years which David reigned in Hebron. We find that from the time that the Ark was abducted until Saul’s death, were thirteen years and seven months, and Samuel died four months before Saul.

text.title: only, may the Lord fulfill His word::

pasuk.text: Since you asked of Him seed of righteous men (above v. 11), and Eli announced to you through divine inspiration: (above v. 17) “The God of Israel will grant your request,” may the Lord fulfill His word. This is according to the simple interpretation. The Midrash Agadah, however, explains thus: Rabbi Nehemiah said in the name of Rabbi Samuel, the son of Rabbi Isaac: Every day, a divine voice would resound throughout the world, and say: A righteous man is destined to arise, and his name will be Samuel. Thereupon, every woman who bore a son, would name him Samuel. As soon as they saw his deeds, they would say, “This is not Samuel.” When our Samuel was born, however, and people saw his deeds, they said, “It seems that this one is the expected righteous man.” This is what Elkanah meant when he said, ‘May the Lord fulfill His word,’ that this be the righteous Samuel.

I heard from Rabbi Isaac Halevi, that she brought one ephah of meal, which is equivalent to three seahs, from which to extract three tenths of an ephah of fine flour, which are required for one bull (Num. 15:8), as we learned in the Mishnah (Men. 76b): The showbread was made of twenty-four tenths of an ephah from twenty-four seahs; i.e., 1 tenth part of an ephah of fine flour from a seah of wheat.

text.title: and an earthenware jug of wine::

pasuk.text: for a drink offering. והנער נער and the child was young (after Jonathan).

text.title: and they brought the child to Eli:

pasuk.text: to see that his prophecy was fulfilled. And our sages, however, expounded what they expounded, that he decided a point of law, that a priest is unnecessary for sacrificial slaughter, as it is stated in Tractate Ber. (31b).
Take care of him that he become your disciple. And according to the Midrash of our sages, not to punish him with death.

text.title: For this child did I pray::

pasuk.text: Do not say, “This one shall die and another one shall be given to you.”

text.title: And I also have lent him to the Lord:

pasuk.text: like a person who lends a utensil to his master, or lends him his son to serve him.
empunte in French, i.e., you have no right to punish him, for the Lord has become a borrower over him, since I have lent him to Him, and He must return him to me.
Samuel, and some say Elkanah.

text.title: My mouth is opened wide against my enemies:

pasuk.text: against Peninnah.

text.title: And there is no rock like our God.:

pasuk.text: There is no artist like our God, Who makes a form within a form (Ber. 10a).

All those who are haughty when good fortune shines upon them. And according to the peshat, she is speaking for the benefit of Peninnah, who behaved haughtily toward her. According to the derash, however, we follow J’s translation.

(Lit.) strong speech. Others explain it as an expression of falsehood, something which is removed from the truth, like ויעתק“and he moved from there to the mountain” (Gen. 12: 8). We, therefore, render: Let not falsehood come out of your mouth.

text.title: For the Lord is a God of thoughts:

pasuk.text: He knows what is in your heart.

text.title: And to Him are deeds counted:

pasuk.text: All men’s deeds are counted before Him. Heb. ‘nithk’nu,’ an expression of number, like: and the number (tochen) of bricks shall you give (Ex. 5:18).

text.title: The bows of the mighty are broken, etc.:

pasuk.text: So is the custom of the Most Holy, blessed be He. He weakens the mighty, and strengthens the weak. He sates the hungry and starves those who are satiated.
and do not need to hire themselves out for any work, He starves them, and they must hire themselves out for their daily bread, while the hungry who would toil and weary themselves for food…

from their toil. While the barren woman has born seven, she that had many children has been bereaved and buries her children. Hannah bore seven, as it is stated: For the Lord remembered Hannah, and she conceived and bore three sons and two daughters (2:21). When Hannah bore four, Peninnah buried eight, and when she conceived and bore a fifth child, Peninnah prostrated herself at her feet, and begged for mercy. Consequently, they lived, and were therefore called on her name. This is Rabbi Nehemiah’s opinion. Rabbi Judah says: Grandchildren are considered like children, (and she saw Samuel’s two sons). Some say: the numerical value of שבעה (seven) is equivalent to that of שמואל, (thus: ש =300, ב =2, ע =70, ה =5, totaling 377. Likewise, ש =300, מ =40, ו =6, א =1, ל =30, totaling 377).

It is spelled חסידו, His pious one. It is read חסידיו, His pious ones, i.e., either a single one or many. Likewise, “Those who strive with the Lord will be broken.” This reading is מריביו, those who strive with Him. The spelling is מריבו, he who strives with Him, i.e., either one or many.

text.title: Upon him will he thunder in Heaven:

pasuk.text: The spelling is עלו, they have ascended, even if they have ascended to the heavens, He thunders upon and casts them down.

text.title: will judge the ends of the earth:

pasuk.text: will judge them; in old French, jostizier.

text.title: was serving the Lord before Eli the priest::

pasuk.text: (The Talmud asks, “Did Samuel actually serve the Lord?” Didn’t he serve before Eli? [He was too young to serve the Lord!] We therefore deduce) from here that whoever serves before a Torah scholar, is considered as though he had served before the Divine Presence.
They themselves established this law, since they rightfully inherited only the breast and the thigh of the peace offering.
דוד is a [small] pot.
קלחת is a large pot.
כי נאצו, an expression of being despised.
(Hebrew ephod.) kardut of linen (Jonathan). This is an expression meaning a robe (מעיל) , for Jonathan renders ‘m’ilim’ in the passage, "for so were the virgins wont to wear robes (m’ilim) kardutin.

text.title: And a small robe his mother would make for him:

pasuk.text: from year to year.
this is the present tense (i.e., he would bless him every year).

text.title: because of the request which he had requested:

pasuk.text: for himself a son. And Eli would say to him, “May the Lord grant seed, etc.” May it be the Divine Will that all the children which you will have, will be from this righteous woman. This is (therefore) an inverted sentence.

This is explained according to the ordinary sense of the passage. Our rabbis, however, said: Since they delayed the sacrifice of their birds, (i.e., of the women who had given birth, or had had an issue. v. Lev. 22:6 8,15:29), and they (the women) would wait until they would see their birds being offered, the Scripture charges them as though they had lain with them.

text.title: which I hear the Lord’s people spreading:

pasuk.text: The rumor which the Lord’s people are spreading about you. This is an expression similar to: “And they caused to be proclaimed in the camp” (Ex. 36: 6). Hence, they let out a rumor about you, which is not good.
(Heb. ‘ufil’lo,’) an expression of judgment, like (Ex. 21:22): and he shall pay as the judges determine (bi-flilim).
Heb. elohim.

text.title: for the Lord desired to kill them:

pasuk.text: For their verdict had already been sealed. Before the verdict is sealed, however, the Scripture states: For I desire not the death of one who dies (Ezek. 17: 32).

text.title: And a man of God came::

pasuk.text: (The Sifrei informs us that the man of God mentioned here) was Elkanah.

text.title: Did I appear to the house of your father:

pasuk.text: From here (we deduce) that Aaron prophesied in Egypt. What was the prophecy? It is that which is stated (Ezek. 20:7), And I said to them: Each man, cast away the detestable things upon which his eyes gaze, and with the idols of Egypt, defile not yourselves.
Did you know that I gave to Aaron this favor and greatness?
which I commanded in My dwelling place.

text.title: to feed yourselves from the first part, etc.:

pasuk.text: (lit., and you honor your sons above Me to feed yourselves from the first part of every offering of Israel to My people.) This is an inverted sentence, (to be explained thus): and you honor your sons above Me before My people, i.e., in the eyes of My people, you honored your son above me. And what is the honor? To feed yourselves from the first part of every offering of Israel. Your meal preceded My meal, as it is stated: Also before they caused the fat to smoke, etc. (above, verse 15).
(Heb. ‘l’havriachem’) An expression of a meal, similar to: Please let my sister feed me bread (Heb. ‘v’thavreni’).
This reverts to: And you honor your sons above Me. You showed to My people that you are more honored than I. And with what have you shown this? To feed yourselves from the first part of My offering.

(Heb. ‘amor amarti’) Twice I assigned greatness to the sons of Ithamar. Concerning the sons of Gershon and the sons of Merari, it is stated: Under the hand of Ithamar, the son of Aaron the Priest. (Num. 4:23, 33). And Eli was one of the descendants of Ithamar. This I found in M.S.(8:3). I have, however, heard a more fitting version, as follows: I said: Your house and your father’s house, etc. Originally, I gave the high priesthood to Eleazar the Priest, as it is stated: And remove from Aaron his garments, and put them on Eleazar, his son (Num. 20:26). At the time of the concubine (in Gibeah, v. Judges 19, 21), when the Israelites freed themselves of most of the Commandments. And who caused them (to do so)? Phinehas and his colleagues, who should have gone around from city to city to reprove them. I, (therefore) took the High Priesthood away from them, and gave it to you, for you are of the descendants of Ithamar, and I said: They shall walk before Me forever, for when greatness is assigned to someone, it is assigned to him and to his generations forever.

text.title: for those who honor Me shall I honor:

pasuk.text: The descendants of Phinehas who honored Me at Shittim (Num. 21:7,8). And so it came about in the days of Solomon, that when he built the Temple, Solomon dismissed Ebiathar from being a priest to the Lord, to fulfill the word of the Lord which He had spoken to the house of Eli (I Kings 2:27), and Zadok became High Priest, since he was of the descendants of Phinehas, for so he is listed in the genealogical records in the Book of Chronicles (I Chron. 6: 35 38).

text.title: and those who despise Me will be disgraced:

pasuk.text: By themselves, when I shall withdraw Myself from them.

text.title: I shall cut off your arm:

pasuk.text: I.e., the power which you exert in My House, for you say: And if not, I shall take by force.

text.title: And you will look upon a rival in My dwelling place:

pasuk.text: And you will see your rival at your side in My dwelling place like a woman who sees her rival with her in the house.

text.title: in all (the days) which (God) will do good to Israel:

pasuk.text: (Lit., in all that which He will do good to Israel.) "When the Temple will be built in the day of Solomon, and the goodness promised to Israel will be complete, as it is said there: There has not failed one word of all His good promise, etc. (I Kings 8:56). Judah and Israel were many, like the sand which is by the sea (ibid. 4:20). And Judah and Israel dwelt in safety, every man under his vine and under his fig tree, etc. all the days of Solomon (ibid. 5:5).

text.title: and there will not be an elder in your household:

pasuk.text: This is an appropriate punishment. You ate sacrifices before their time, before they made the fat smoke, similarly, you will die before your time.
(Heb. ‘v’la’div,’) same as ‘v’lad’iv.’
(Lit., will die men.) There is no comparison between mourning for a young man and mourning for a child.

text.title: And this is the sign to you:

pasuk.text: That the prophecy will be fulfilled: In one day your two sons will die, and this will be to you a sign that all the retribution which was said to you, will be fulfilled. I.e., “And you will look upon a rival in My dwelling place, etc., and all those raised in your house will die as young men” (above 32, 33).
i.e., Zadok.
In order to earn a coin called ‘ma’ah.’
(Heb. Agorath Kesef,) a silver piece of the weights of twenty gerah (Exod. 30:13). ספחני Take me… into.
(Heb. ‘yakar,’ dear.) And similarly, (Prov. 17:27) ‘y’kar ruach’ one whose breath is dear is an understanding man, meaning, one whose speech is withheld is an understanding man.
Prophecy was not revealed (Jonathan). ‘Nifratz,’ an expression similar to ‘ufaratzta,’ and you shall spread westward and eastward (Gen. 28:14).
In his place, in the court of the Levites who watch in the Temple. Jonathan paraphrases thus: And Samuel was lying in the court of the Levites…
where the Ark of God was,…

And a voice emanated from the Temple of God, from the Holy of Holies, which called, ‘Samuel!’ The end of the above verse is connected to the beginning of the following verse. This is what is inferred by the Scriptural verse (Job 37:5): The Lord thunders wondrously with His voice….Now, Eli was a priest, and was watching from within, while Samuel was lying without. Yet, the voice jumped over Eli to Samuel. Tractate Tamid.

text.title: had not yet known the Lord:

pasuk.text: (Heb. ‘terem,’) i.e., he had not yet recognized the nature of the prophetic voice. Every ‘terem’ in the Scriptures is an expression of ‘not yet,’ and is not an expression of ‘before.’ This instance proves this supposition. Furthermore, the passage: “That you do not yet fear” (Exod. 9:30), is more explicit than this. Also, “No shrub of the field was yet on the earth” (Gen. 2:5).
He did not mention the Name of the Deity as Eli had commanded him, for he said (to himself), “Perhaps it is another voice.”

text.title: I am about to do something:

pasuk.text: This is the capture of the Ark by the Philistines.
(Heb. ‘t’zillenah,’) an expression similar to ‘zelz’lim,’ cymbals, retentir, in French, to resound, ring.

On that day, My decree upon Eli’s house will commence (to be fulfilled), for Hophni and Phinehas shall die and from then on, I shall finish My decree and complete it upon them from generation to generation, to cause them to die (as young) men of eighteen years.
Commencant et accomplissant, in French.

text.title: that his sons are bringing disgrace upon themselves:

pasuk.text: (Lit. disgrace or despise themselves.) It should properly state “despise Me,” but the Scripture euphemized.
usually rendered ‘curse’) and likewise, every curse is an expression of irreverence and disgrace.

text.title: and he did not rebuke them:

pasuk.text: And he did not darken them; i.e., he did not darken their faces by removing them from their high office.

text.title: So shall God do to you:

pasuk.text: like that very curse, that you shall not have worthy children. And that (curse actually) befell him (Infra 7:3), even though he told him (Eli).
(Deducing) from here, (our Sages) stated: A curse of a wise man, even though pronounced on condition, will be realized.
he is Master, and everything belongs to Him.

text.title: for the Lord revealed Himself to Samuel:

pasuk.text: Since the Scripture stated above (2:1) “and the word of the Lord was withheld in those days,” he states here that from now on, for Samuel’s sake, He revealed Himself repeatedly.

text.title: And the word of Samuel was to all Israel, and Israel went out to war:

pasuk.text: I.e., the word which was said to Samuel, was fulfilled, and came to all Israel. Now, how did this misfortune (befall them)? And Israel went out to war against the Philistines.
This was not yet its name, for it was first called this (name) in Samuel’s time, but here the Scripture calls it by its future name.
(Heb. ‘vatitosh’) similar to “and behold they were spread over the face of the earth” (Heb. ‘n’tushim’) (infra 30:16), “and they were scattered by the jaw bone,” (Heb. ‘vayinat’shu’) (Judges 15: 9).

text.title: with every (sort of) plague in the wilderness::

pasuk.text: By the Reed Sea. Jonathan, however, renders: (These are the mighty deeds of God, Who smote Egypt with every sort of plague,) and for His people He performed wonders in the wilderness. In Sifrei (Behaaloth’cha), we learned that this passage is a combination of statements. The worthy among them said, “Who will save us from the hand of this mighty God?” while the wicked among them retorted, “This is the God Who smote the Egyptians with every plague.” All the plagues which He had, He brought upon the Egyptians. Thenceforth, He has no plagues.
This was Saul, who grabbed the tablets from the hands of Goliath and fled.
By the place of the road, he was anxiously waiting.
(Heb. ‘mafrakto’) ‘targum mafrakuthei’ the bone of the neck.

text.title: was with child, ready to give birth:

pasuk.text: (Heb. ‘lolath.’) We are compelled (to agree) that the meaning of this word, is ‘to give birth,’ like ‘laledeth,’ although (the daleth is missing), and there is no similar form (in the Scriptures). Menahem, (however,) joined this (with other verb forms) in the section dealing with the word, ‘yelalah,’ wailing, because her birth pangs came upon her with wailing. The root of the word ‘yelalah,’ is the ‘lamed’ alone.
They were unnatural, and that is why she died.
(translation follows Metzudas Zion. Rashi, however, explains it as ‘hinges’;) i.e., the hinges of the doors of her womb, in French, charniere.
There is no glory, like ‘ein kabod.’ Similarly (Job 22:30), He will save ‘i naki’ one who is not innocent, like ‘ein naki.’

text.title: because the Ark of God has been taken:

pasuk.text: (Lit., to the being taken of the Ark of God.) Like “because of the being taken of the Ark of God,” but it is unnecessary to remove it from the expression of ‘to’ for the one who understands its meaning.

text.title: because the Ark of God was taken:

pasuk.text: In French, “envers l’etre pris,” (concerning the being taken).
and because of this misfortune that her father- in-law and husband had perished.
An idol made in the likeness of a fish.
(Heb. ‘ha miftan,’) equivalent to the Mishnaic ‘askupah.’
(Heb. ‘va’y’shimmem,’) an expression of desolation (‘sh’mamah’).
(‘t’chorim’ refers to) the mesentery of the large intestine; (i.e., He smote them with) a plague of the rectum. Mice would enter their recta, disembowel them, and crawl out.

(Heb. ‘vayisath’ru,’ spelled with a ‘sien,’) identical with ‘vayisath’ru’ (spelled with a ‘samech,’) for it is listed in the Masora, among those words written with a ‘sien,’ and explained as though written with a ‘samech.’ I.e., there was a plague in the hidden parts of the body.

All panics (mentioned in the Scriptures) are caused by thunder; the following is the origin thereof: “And the Lord thundered with a mighty voice on that day upon the Philistines, and He threw them into confusion” (infra 7:10). This is explained in the Aggadah of Thirty two Rules of Rabbi Eliezer, the son of Rabbi Jose the Galilean (not found in our edition).
In what manner shall we send it away, so that He will not be angry, and so that His wrath will be removed from us.
An indication that you confess that you have betrayed Him.

text.title: Then you will be cured, and it will be known to you:

pasuk.text: that He did this, for why wouldn’t His hand turn away from you then?
They were five, as it is stated (Jos. 13:3): “The Gazite and the Ashdodite, the Ashkelonite, the Gittite, and the Ekronite.”
milch cows.

text.title: upon which no yoke has (ever) come:

pasuk.text: This is for the test. Since these cows are not capable of pulling a load, and furthermore, they will low after their young, if the Ark will have the power to enable them to pull it by themselves, we shall know that He wrought this upon us.
escrin in French.

text.title: they shut up in the house:

pasuk.text: (Heb. ‘kalu,’) an expression of imprisonment, ‘kele.’

(Heb. ‘vayisharnah,’ aggadically interpreted as ‘sang’ from the root ‘shir.’) This word is a grammatical hermaphrodite (possessing the preformative ‘yod’ of the masculine and the afformative ‘nun’ ‘heh’ of the feminine). This teaches us that even the young (hence masculine) recited a song, viz., “Sing aloud, sing aloud, O Ark of acacia wood! Exalt yourself with the greatness of your splendor, you who are girded with golden embroidery, you who are praised with the scroll of the palace (Moses’ scroll of the Pentateuch), and lauded with choice ornaments,” (Tractate Abodah Zarah 24b). According to its simple meaning, it is an expression meaning ‘straight,’ i.e., they followed a straight path.
(Heb. ‘haloch v’gao.’) This is an expression of the cry of the cattle.
[The people of] Israel were there.
They were gazing to see how it came alone, and out of their joy, they behaved with levity, for they did not gaze at it with awe and respect.
A village without a wall.

text.title: and even to the great stone:

pasuk.text: (Heb. ‘abel,’ mourning.) This is the aforementioned great stone, for the ‘lamed’ comes in place of the ‘nun’ (in ‘eben’), similar to ‘nishkah’ instead of ‘lishkah’ (chamber), in the book of Nehemiah (13:7), since they experienced mourning at that spot, (v. infra 6:19), they called it Abel.

Jonathan renders: And He killed of the elders of the people seventy men, and of the community, fifty thousand men. Our Rabbis, however, said: Seventy men, each of whom was equal to fifty thousand, or fifty thousand men, each of whom was equal to the seventy of the Sanhedrin.
they designated (after Jonathan).

text.title: from the day the Ark was stationed in Kiriath-jearim:

pasuk.text: And they saw the retribution which befell them because of the sin of the house of Eli and the mighty deed which the Holy One, Blessed be He, had performed against the Philistines.

text.title: and all the house of Israel were drawn after the Lord:

pasuk.text: through Samuel who would travel from city to city, judging and reproving them. Heb. ‘va’yinahu,’ an expression of drawing, in Aramaic, similar to Jonathan, who paraphrases: And they were drawn after the worship of God. And similarly (Ez. 7:11) ‘v’lo noah bahem’ and there is no use to attract them to good. Menahem classifies this thus: ‘Va’yinahu’ is an expression of lamentation, like (Micah 2:4): ‘nehi nihyah’ “a lamentation shall be wailed.” And likewise, ‘v’lo noah bahem’ (will be explained “and they have no remorse”). And the meaning of our verse is: They lamented their evil deeds, and returned after the Lord. Another explanation is that ‘va’yinahu’ means “and they gathered.” “And all nations will be gathered into it (Jerusalem)” (Jer. 3:17). Jonathan renders: And all nations will gather (‘v’yithnahon’) to worship therein. The quotation from Ezekiel may also be rendered in this manner: neither from them, nor from their multitude… nor from their gathering.

Jonathan renders: and they poured out their hearts in repentance, like water, before the Lord. And according to its simple meaning, it is merely a symbol of humility, i.e., they implied, we are like spilled water.
between two litigants on monetary matters which came up between them, or concerning sins which they had committed.

text.title: and offered it up as a burnt offering:

pasuk.text: The kethiv is ‘vayaaleha’ fem. gender, because it was a female. Hence, our Rabbis deduced that a female animal is acceptable for a burnt offering in a private high place, in Tractate Abodah Zarah.
below Beth-sharon (from Jonathan).
(Heb. ‘shen,’ a tooth or peak) i.e., the peak of the rock.
They themselves; (i.e., ‘va’yittu’ is an intransitive verb, of the ‘kal’ or simple conjugation).

Something else; viz. justice. (I. e., ‘va’yattu’ is a transitive verb of the ‘hiph’il’ or causative conjugation.) And our Rabbis said: Samuel’s sons did not sin. They merely did not follow their father’s footsteps. While their father would travel to all places of Israel and judge them in their cities they did not do so, in order to increase the income of their sheriffs and scribes, (who were employed to summon the litigants to trial).
because they said, ‘to judge us like all the nations.’
that the fear of their king be upon them.
to make them craftsmen, blacksmiths and carpenters.
who prepare perfumes and spices for women’s cosmetics.
(Jonathan renders:) into the land wherein there was a prophet.
like ‘Zopheh,’ a prophet, or seer).

text.title: lest my father cease to worry about the she-asses:

pasuk.text: because his worry for us will increase until he forgets the she-asses.
doutera in French.
The story of the she-asses, i.e., what has become of them, for whom we have gone all this way.

text.title: and what shall we bring to the man:

pasuk.text: Jonathan paraphrases: If he accepts money, what shall we bring to the man? Saul was not familiar with Samuel’s practice and thought that he would ask for a reward.

(Heb ‘t’shurah’) Jonathan renders: and there is nothing proper. This is an expression of ‘yosher,’ propriety. (The root is ‘yashor.’ The yud is missing, and the ‘tav’ is a prefix.) Menahem, however, explains ‘t’shurah’ as an expression of an offering for the privilege of seeing a king or an important person. An expression related to ‘ashurenu,’ “I behold them” (Num. 24: 17). And his opinion is acceptable to me.
one zuz of silver (from Jonathan).
The author wrote this. This is not part of the statement of Saul’s servant.

text.title: for he who is called prophet today:

pasuk.text: (lit., to the prophet today.) The one who is called a prophet today, was formerly called a seer.

text.title: When you come to the city, straightway:

pasuk.text: They prolonged their conversation in order to gaze upon Saul’s handsomeness.
Jonathan renders: to the banquet hall. When Shiloh was destroyed, the high places were permitted, and they would sacrifice peace- offerings in the high place and eat together.

text.title: for he will bless the sacrifice:

pasuk.text: Jonathan renders: for he will break bread. For the peace-offering they recited the following benediction: Blessed are You, O Lord our God, King of the universe, Who has sanctified us with His commandments, and commanded us to eat the sacrifice.
just as the day exists.

(Heb. ‘yazor,’ will restrain,) meaning ‘will rule,’ similar to “restrained (azur) and let free” (Deut. 32:36). So is the function of the ruler, viz., to restrain the people during a war, that they do not scatter, and that they do not spread out from one another, and to restrain everyone from doing evil. In our language, we call ‘maazor’ (restraint) contenir, in French.
(The Heb. is ‘vayigash,’ accompanied by ‘eth’ instead of the usual ‘el’, to. Therefore,) Jonathan interprets this as: And Saul met Samuel (similar to ‘vayifgash’).

text.title: and to whom does all that is desirable in Israel belong?:

pasuk.text: He came here to hint to him the matter of the kingdom.

text.title: at the head of the invited guests:

pasuk.text: in the place where the most important people are seated, for from the manner of the seating, it was apparent in which place the most important person sat.
Since Samuel knew that Saul would come, he ordered to give him a handsome portion for his benefit.

text.title: the thigh and that which was upon it:

pasuk.text: I.e., the thigh and the hip which is above it.

text.title: Behold that which has been reserved:

pasuk.text: from the portions of the invited guests, and has been set aside for you.

In the final chapter of Tractate Zeb. 119b, it is established that (the waving of) the breast and thigh is (practiced) in a large (public) high place, but the waving of the breast and thigh is not (practiced) in a small (private) high place. It was, therefore, permissible for Saul to eat.

text.title: because for the appointed time it is reserved:

pasuk.text: because for the appointed time of the banquet, this thigh was reserved for you.

text.title: by saying, “I have invited the people.”:

pasuk.text: My statement was to the cook, (as follows): ‘I invited the people to the feast, and I know their number. Be careful with their portions.’ And I gave (assigned) him the portions according to their number, and this was reserved for you.

text.title: and he spoke with Saul on the roof:

pasuk.text: reproving him and teaching him to fear the Holy One, Blessed be He.
to go far from us so that he will not overhear our conversation.
The servant went ahead of them, and to Saul he said, “And you stand still with me.”

text.title: by Rachel’s tomb, in the border of Benjamin:

pasuk.text: Now, isn’t Rachel’s tomb in the border of Judah, in Bethlehem? Rather, (this is the meaning:) Now, they are by Rachel’s tomb, and when you will meet them, you will find them in the border of Benjamin, in Zelzah. Thus taught the Rabbis in the Tosefta of Tractate Sotah. Zelzah is a combination of the words: ‘zel l’zah,’ the shadow of the Fair One, of the Holy One, Blessed be He, Who is fair and ruddy (So described in Song of Songs 5:10). And this is Jerusalem.
fears concerning you, and likewise, every expression of worry (d’agah) is an expression of fear. Douter in French.
the plain of Tabor.
the hill of Kiriath-jearim, where the Ark of God was now (stationed).
officers whom they had appointed over Israel for they were ruling over them and stationing officers in the cities of Israel.
(Heb. ‘hevel n’viim’) Jonathan renders: a band of scribes. ‘Hevel’ is a band. Likewise, “The bands of sheol surrounded me” (II Sam. 22:6) is rendered: The camps of the wicked surrounded me.
Jonathan renders from the banquet hall.

text.title: And it will be that when these signs will come to you:

pasuk.text: And you will know that my words are true, for just as these signs will have come to you, so will the matter of the kingdom be fulfilled.

text.title: do for yourself what your hand will find:

pasuk.text: Prepare for yourself regal garments (Jonathan), and prepare for yourself the court ceremonial.

text.title: And you shall come down before me to Gilgal:

pasuk.text: And after you reign, you shall come down to Gilgal before me, i.e., before I come down.

text.title: and behold, I shall go down to you:

pasuk.text: at the termination of seven days after you will have gone down. תוחל shall you wait.
a spirit of regal power.
Why do you wonder about the matter “Who is the father of the prophets? Is prophecy hereditary?”

text.title: and the matter of the kingdom he did not tell him.:

pasuk.text: He possessed the trait of discretion.
Even though he was not there, the lot fell upon him, for their names were written on pieces of parchment and placed in a box. Now the Prophet would insert his hand and take one piece of parchment.

(Heb. ‘el hakelim,’ lit., to the vessels,) to the house where the comers had placed their baggage. (He did this) because he was fleeing the high position. And the Midrash Agadah of Rabbi Tanhuma (Levit. 1) explains: ‘to the vessels’ as referring to the Urim and Tummim. He said, ‘Perhaps I am not worthy of this high position. (I shall not assume it) until they ask of the Urim and Tummim.’ Thereupon they asked, and he achieved it.
(Jonathan renders:) sin fearing men, in whose heart God had given fear.

(We explain this) literally, but the Midrash Agadah (MS. 14:7) (explains it figuratively): He said, “Bring me your Torah which was given by the right hand (of the Almighty),” (Deut. 33:2), and I shall burn it, because He wrote therein: “An Ammonite and a Moabite shall not enter the congregation of the Lord” (Deut. 23:3).
an insult.
after the appointed time that the cattle come in from the field.
to his animals.

text.title: And he counted them in Bezek:

pasuk.text: Our Rabbis said: (He counted them) with fragments of earthenware. (I. e., ‘bezek’ is a common noun, not the name of a place.) (Yoma 22b) (The following does not appear in certain editions of Rashi.) Another explanation is that ‘b’vezek’ means ‘with pebbles,’ i.e., he took a pebble from each one, and counted them, similar to “And he counted them with lambs” (infra 15:4), which means that he took a lamb from each one, and counted them therewith, just as they would count them with half shekels. In (Prov. 26: 8) “like a pebble for throwing in a slingshot,” the Targum uses the word ‘bizka.’ And in Midrash Yelam’denu (T. Ki Thissa 9, Buber 8) “And he counted them with lambs.” When they were poor, they were counted with pebbles; when they became rich, they were counted with lambs. Another explanation is that ‘bezek’ is the name of a place, mentioned (in Judges 1:5): “And they found Adoni-bezek in Bezek.”
derisively, “Saul will reign over us?” give them over, and let us put them to death.
as a question.

text.title: And Samuel said, etc.,… and let us renew there the kingdom:

pasuk.text: Since previously, there was opposition in the matter, and now they were all agreeable.

text.title: and I have become old and hoary:

pasuk.text: Our Rabbis said that he aged prematurely, as it is stated in Tractate Taanith (5b).
for my work.

text.title: or whose ass did I take:

pasuk.text: When I used to go from city to city to judge them concerning their needs, I used to go on my own ass, although I should have taken (one) of theirs.
Every expression of ‘meruzah’ which follows ‘oshek’ (robbery), is an expression of “robbed and oppressed” (Deut. 28:33), one who robs the poor and oppresses them.

text.title: that I hide my eyes therewith:

pasuk.text: in order to hide my eyes from the judgment because of the money.

text.title: and I shall restore to you:

pasuk.text: all that you will say.

(lit., ‘and he said.’ The Rabbis, taking the word literally, explain that) a bath kol (a heavenly voice) came forth and said, ‘I am witness.’ This was one of three places in which the holy spirit entered the earthly court, as it is stated in Tractate Makkoth (23b).
to be prepared for His mission to take your forefathers out of Egypt.
or debate.
This is Gideon (Jud. 6:32).
This is Samson who came from the tribe of Dan.

Here are three insignificant leaders with three eminent leaders: Moses, Aaron, and Samuel, to tell you that the insignificant leader in his generation is equal to the eminent leader in his generation. Every court which is appointed over the generation must be followed as though its members were the noblest of nobility.

text.title: both you and the king who reigns over you will be:

pasuk.text: Both you and the king who reigns over you will live to a ripe old age.

text.title: the Lord’s hand will be against you and against your fathers:

pasuk.text: Meaning, after it was against your fathers. Our Rabbis, however, said: (Jeb. 63b) “against you and against your fathers” refers to the digging up of the dead, which is a visitation of disgrace upon the dead.

and just as through my prayer, I am able to change the seasons, similarly, if a war befell you, there would be power in my prayer to protect you against the adversary, and you had no need to ask for a king during my lifetime despite the fact that I am old.

text.title: Is it not wheat harvest today?:

pasuk.text: Rain is an evil omen (Taanith 12b), and the Holy One Blessed be He is reluctant to visit retribution for nothing. Nevertheless, I have power; I shall call to the Lord, and He will send thunder and rain.

text.title: and you shall know and see:

pasuk.text: that it was unnecessary to ask for a king and to treat me with disrespect.
for His Name has spread concerning you, that He is your Savior and lest the Name of His greatness be diminished.
(Heb. ‘ho il,’) like (infra 14:24) “And Saul made the people swear (Heb. ‘vayoel’).”

text.title: also far be it from me:

pasuk.text: Since you will do your part by returning to the Lord, I also, far be it from me to stop praying for you.

text.title: Saul was a year in his reign:

pasuk.text: (lit., a year old.) Our Rabbis of sainted memory said: Like a one year old, who did not experience the taste of sin (Yoma 22b). It may also be interpreted thus: Saul was a year in his reign, i.e., in the first year in which he was made king (and he reigned two years over Israel), and in the first year, immediately, Saul chose for himself three thousand.
They had an officer over Israel whom they had stationed in Gibeah of Benjamin.
that we have rebelled against the Philistines, and let them beware of them.

text.title: and also Israel has become hateful:

pasuk.text: Lit., they have come in bad odor with the Philistines. An expression of hatred.
This is what Samuel had said to him (supra 10: 8), “And you shall come down before me to Gilgal.”
(Heb. ‘kidmath’) same as ‘mizrach’ Beth- aven.
a place where thorns are concentrated. Epine in French (thorn).
(as a forest in which the trees and branches are bent over all around the forest,) Plisse in French (folded).
Holes [in the ground].

text.title: And some Hebrews crossed the Jordan to the land of Gad:

pasuk.text: to flee from before the Philistines since the Philistines were in the land of Canaan on the west side of the Jordan.
(lit. trembled after him;) i.e., they hurried to go after him.
And he waited.

text.title: to the appointed time which Samuel:

pasuk.text: this is a short verse, with one word missing. (We must explain:) to the appointed time which Samuel had set, or to the appointed time of Samuel. And an example of this, we find (II Samuel 4:2) “And two men, officers of troops were the son of Saul.” He should have written: were to the son of Saul (or the son of Saul had). Here too, ‘which was to Samuel’ (or ‘of Samuel’), who said to him, “Seven days shall you wait until I come to you” (supra 10:8).

text.title: Bring near to me the burnt offering:

pasuk.text: A stranger (non-priest) is permitted to sacrifice on a high place.
Did I not say to you, ‘Behold I shall come down to you to offer up the burnt offering?’ I should offer it up, and not you.

text.title: at the appointed time of the days:

pasuk.text: at the beginning of the day.
I overcame my will, for my heart told me to wait for you, and against my will I suppressed my heart, and offered up the burnt offering.
Before you did this.

text.title: the Lord would have established your kingdom over Israel forever:

pasuk.text: for when a high position is assigned to a person, it is assigned to him and to his posterity.

text.title: But now, your kingdom shall not continue:

pasuk.text: for so said Moses in the Torah, “and that he turn not aside from the commandment right or left, in order that he prolong his days, etc.” (Deut. 17:20). Hence, if he turns aside, he will not prolong his days. And if you will argue that this was not said in reference to a commandment of a Prophet, but only in reference to a commandment of the Torah, (I shall answer you that) it was already stated: “and to observe all the words of the Law,” and afterwards, “that his heart be not lifted up above his brothers, and that he turn not aside from the commandment,” (meaning) even from a commandment of a Prophet.
(lit., who were found with him) for the people had scattered from him, and these remained.

where the ‘zeboim’ were found. This is the creature referred to by Rabbi Meir when he said: also the zabua (The owner is considered forewarned to pay the full damage the first time it damages B.K. 16a). Jonathan renders: ‘af’aya,’ and so did our Rabbis of sainted memory, explain: ‘zabua’ is ‘eph’eh,’ a species of fierce and destructive reptiles.

text.title: Now, not a smith was to be found:

pasuk.text: Not one was found at the beginning of Saul’s reign, because the Philistines who ruled over Israel, dismissed all the ironsmiths from Israel, lest they make weapons to wage war.

text.title: And all Israel went down (to the land of) the Philistines:

pasuk.text: And when the Israelites needed ironsmiths to sharpen colters and axes and mattocks, they were forced to go down to the land of the Philistines.
(Heb. ‘maharashto’) ‘soc’ in French (a plowshare).
(Heb. ‘eitho’) ‘coutre’ in French (a colter).
(Heb. ‘kardumo’) ‘baisague’ in French (a twibil or axe).
(Heb. ‘mahareishatho’) ‘pioche’ in French (a mattock or pickaxe).

text.title: And there was the file for the mattocks:

pasuk.text: And those who found it overly troublesome to go down to the Philistines to sharpen had an implement called ‘pezirah pim,’ ‘lime’ in French (a file), which has many mouths, i.e., many sharp surfaces. They had this to sharpen the mattocks and the colters.
a fork made like a sort of pitchfork, which is called ‘fourche’ (a pitchfork), having three prongs.
to sharpen it at the tip, to insert it, and set it into the handle.
(lit., and there was found to Saul) through a miracle.
It is the custom of soldiers to form a garrison and a raiding party. The raiding party is composed of those who spread out into a city in quest of plunder. This is called ‘gens pille’ (plunderers).
They are the officers who stand guard that no raiders come out of the city against them.

The Philistines were encamped in Michmash and Michmash was on a mountain. And the Israelites were in a city named Geba and Geba was also at the top of a mountain, and those two mountains were opposite one another, and the valley was between them, as is stated in this episode, “and the garrison of the Philistines approached the other side of Michmash,” which is on the side toward Geba, (i.e., they approached) the valley between them.

(Heb. ‘ha-laz.’) Every ‘ha’laz’ and ‘lazeh’ in the Scriptures is not an expression of ‘ha-zeh’ (this), but it is something which is opposite the speaker, and he points it out with his finger. It is not an expression of ‘cet,’ (this), but of ‘celle’ (that) in French.
of the valley between the two mountains.
(Heb. ‘bik’zeh’) at the edge of Gibeah.
(This includes the ‘hoshen’ with the) urim and tummim.

text.title: And between the sides which Jonathan sought to cross:

pasuk.text: (Thus was the layout of the terrain, lit.) Thus it was made. There was a rocky crag from this side of ‘between the sides,’ and there was a rocky crag from the other side of ‘between the sides.’ The valley is called ‘between the sides,’ and it had a stone from here and a stone from here, one on this side and one on the other side, and the valley was between the two sides. It was that valley that Jonathan sought to cross.
The name of one crag was Bozez and the name of the second was Seneh.
slanting from the north side toward Michmash.
whence Jonathan emerged.

(Heb. ‘domu’) Wait, like: “Sun, wait in Gibeon” (Jos. 10: 12), and so, “Wait for the Lord” (Ps. 37:7). If they say thus, “Wait, and we shall go up to you,” they are prosperous at this time, and they are proud.

text.title: And if they say thus, ‘Come up to us,’ then shall we go up.:

pasuk.text: A fear inspired by the Holy One Blessed be He is in their heart, and they are afraid to move from their place.
(Heb. ‘va’ya’anu,) an expression of raising the voice.

text.title: on his hands and on his feet:

pasuk.text: i.e., with all his might and running.

text.title: in about half a furrow, (which) a yoke (of oxen plow in) a field:

pasuk.text: (He killed them) within the limit of a land measure, viz., the amount of half a furrow of the plowing of a yoke of oxen plowing a field.
(Heb. ‘ma’anah’) That is the ridge which is called ‘rainure’ (ridge or furrow) in French. It was a very mighty deed, because they were close to one another and ready to aid one another.
the lookouts whom Saul had in Gibeah of Benjamin. Lookouts (Heb. ‘zophim’) ‘esculca’ in Old French.
of the Philistines wandered from its place and continuously came nearer to there, to the side of the Israelites.
Like ‘wandering and moving.’
An expression of supervision, like “And should inspect him every morning” (Job 7:18).

text.title: Bring near the Ark of God:

pasuk.text: Urim and Tummim.

text.title: for the Ark of God was on that day:

pasuk.text: This verse is missing one word: for the Ark of God was there on that day.

text.title: And the Hebrews (who) were with the Philistines:

pasuk.text: at their aid out of fear, in earlier times, today they too turned with their fellows to be at the assistance of their brethren.

text.title: And the men of Israel were hard pressed:

pasuk.text: They were being rushed and pressed to wage war against the Philistines.
(Heb. ‘va’yo’el.’) an expression of an oath.
(Heb. ‘lehem,’ lit. bread) All food is included in the meaning of this word, like “Let us destroy the tree with its fruit.” (Heb. ‘b’lahmo’) (Jer. 11:19).
Cane sugar grows in Eretz Israel.
which was flowing from the canes.

(Heb. ‘ya’rath D’vash,’ lit. the forest of honey.) into the sugar cane, like “and she placed it in the reeds” (Exod. 2:3) which Onkelos renders: and she placed it in the ‘yaar,’ and reeds are grasses which grow in the swamp. (Hence, we find that a group or clump of grasses or canes, may be referred to as ‘yaar.’) And so, “I ate my sugar cane with my sugar,” (S. of S. 5:1), and in Arabic, that honey is called ‘sukra’ in their language. (sic) From Rabbi Nathan the Ishmaelite.

text.title: My father has perturbed the land:

pasuk.text: (Heb. ‘achar’) He confused their thoughts, and (hindered) their salvation, like unclear water (‘maim 'achurim’).

text.title: would there not now have been a greater slaughter among the Philistines?:

pasuk.text: This is a question.
(Heb. ‘va’ya’at,’) similar to ‘va’yo’at bahem’ (infra 25:14) “and he drove them away (He made them fly),” an expression of ‘ayit’ (birds of prey) who swoop down on their victims (Gen. 15:11).

(lit., oxen and young of oxen) I say that this was a violation of the precept: You must not slaughter it and its young on the same day (Lev. 23:28). He, therefore, called them sinners (infra v. 33). But our Rabbis said in Tractate Zebahim (120a) that they sanctified them for peace- offerings, and they were eating before the sprinkling of the blood. This is what the Scripture means when it states: “And the people ate with the blood,” they ate when the blood was yet in the basin.
(Heb. ‘golu’) like ‘gil’lu.’

while it is yet daytime, and below (v. 34) it is stated: and all the people brought near, each man his ox in his hand that night. 0ur Rabbis at the end of Tractate Zebahim (120a) hold diverse views. Some of them explain: Here (v. 34) (the Scripture is referring to) ordinary animals, while here (v. 33) (the Scripture is referring to) sacrificial animals. Others explained: Here (v. 33) (the Scripture is referring to) sacrificial animals which were sanctified to be offered at the large high place in Nob, while here (v. 34) (the Scripture is referring to) sacrificial animals which were sanctified to be offered at a small high place. The Scripture thereby teaches us that a private burnt offering may be slaughtered at night (in a small, or private high place).
He made it a high place to sprinkle the blood thereon and for burning the fatty parts.
Announce in many places, and let the announcers disperse among the people.
(Heb. ‘bazeh,’ lit. ‘in this’ or ‘with this’) Here is the place of slaughtering. Another explanation is: He examined a slaughtering knife for them.
The ordinary animals were slaughtered at night. Thus it is explained in Zeb.
That altar was the first of the altars which Saul built.
(lit., the corners of the people) i.e., the chiefs of the people. The cornerstone is the most esteemed.
to cast lots between all of you, and us.
Give a true lot.
innocent, from the lot.
They nullified Saul’s oath for him.
And he gathered an army.

And Ner was Saul’s uncle, the brother of Kish, and they were both the sons of Abiel. Abiel was also known as Ner, in (I) Chron. (8:33), because he would light candles for the public in the dark streets.
This is a present tense, meaning: And when Saul would see a valiant soldier, he would bring him in to himself.

text.title: and now, hearken to the voice of the words of the Lord:

pasuk.text: Once you acted foolishly. Now, take heed.
for they were sorcerers, and they would change themselves to resemble animals.
An expression of announcing, as though it would say, שאול ויזעק.

text.title: and he counted them in Telaim:

pasuk.text: (According to ‘peshat,’ this is the name of a place, as in Jos. 15:24. Our Rabbis, however, take it as a common noun, meaning ‘with lambs,’ explaining thus:) He told everyone to take a lamb from the King’s flocks, since it is forbidden to count Jews, for it is stated concerning them: “which will not be counted for multitude” (Gen. 32:12).

text.title: and he fought in the valley:

pasuk.text: (וירב) and he fought in the valley (from ריב, a quarrel). Our Rabbis said: Concerning the valley, he argued and concluded, thus: if for the sake of one soul, the Torah said, “decapitate a calf in the valley” (Deut. 21), how much more for the sake of all these souls. If man has sinned, what have the animals sinned?

the descendants of Jethro, who were residing in the wilderness of Judea, in the south of Arad, who went to Jabez to learn Torah, Arad being Amalek. The Canaanite king of Arad was Amalek, for it is stated: “the dweller of the South” (Num. 21:1), and “Amalek dwells in the Southland” (ibid. 12:29).

text.title: with all the children of Israel:

pasuk.text: for Moses, Aaron, and all the elders of Israel partook of his (Jethro’s) repast (Ex. 18:12). (The Scripture, therefore) considers it as though he had done kindness with all the children of Israel.

(Heb. ‘vehamishnim.’) It has no likeness (to any other word in the Scriptures). These are the fatlings, and I say that the expression of ‘mishnim’ is like ‘kesef mishneh’ (double money Gen. 43:15) because they are doubled over with flesh and fat. Similarly, (we explain:) “And the ox which was fattened (sheni) seven years.” (Jud. 6:25).
(נמבזה) like נבזה (despised), and the ‘mem’ is superfluous.
A thought has arisen in my heart concerning the kingdom of Saul, whom I have appointed king.

text.title: he is setting up a place for himself:

pasuk.text: He is building an altar for himself. That is the altar referred to concerning Elijah, “And he repaired the altar of the Lord, which had been torn down.” Jonathan however, renders: and behold, he is setting up there a place for himself, to divide the spoils.
Like the Targum, ‘orich,’ meaning ‘wait’.

text.title: are you not the head of the tribes of Israel:

pasuk.text: Jonathan renders: The tribe of Benjamin crossed the Reed Sea at the head of the people, as it is said: “Benjamin, the youngest, rules over them” (Ps. 68: 28).
The people who are with you will destroy them.
(ותעט,) like ותעף (and you flew), an expression relating to עיט, bird of prey (Gen. 15:11).

(ראשית, lit., the beginning), and similarly, “the best of your corn” (Deut. 18: 4), as it is said: “When you separate the best part of it therefrom” (Num. 18:30). Jonathan however, renders: before they banned it.
His command is better than a peace-offering.

text.title: to hearken, than the fat of rams.:

pasuk.text: This refers to: Behold, to obey is better than a peace- offering, and to hearken (is better) than the fat of rams.

text.title: For rebellion is as the sin of divination, and stubbornness is as idolatry and teraphim:

pasuk.text: And like the penalty for idolatry and teraphim, so is the penalty for stubbornness. Jonathan renders: for, as the sin of a people who divine, so is the sin of any man who disobeys the word of the Lord; and as the sins of a nation who has strayed after idols, so is the sin of any person who adds to the words of a prophet.
An expression of adding, and similarly, (Gen. 36:11) He prevailed upon him (ויפצר). He spoke many words to convince him.
Doeg the Edomite, who was as esteemed as all of them.

text.title: and he seized the skirt of his robe:

pasuk.text: According to the simple interpretation, the implication is that when Samuel turned to go away from following Saul, Saul seized the skirt of Samuel’s robe, since Saul was entreating him to return until he would prostrate himself in Gilgal, where the tent of meeting had been. In Midrash Aggadah, however, Amoraim differ on this point. Some say that Saul tore Samuel’s robe, and some say that Samuel tore Saul’s robe, thereby giving over to him this sign, that whoever would sever the skirt of his robe would reign in his place. And that is what Saul said to David on the day that he severed the robe, “I know that you will reign” (infra 24:21).

text.title: And also, the Strength of Israel will neither lie:

pasuk.text: And if you say, “I shall repent of my sin before Him, it will no longer avail to take the kingdom from the one to whom it was given, for the Holy One, Blessed be He, Who is the Strength of Israel, will not lie by not giving the good to whom He promised to give it.”

text.title: And Agag went to him delicately:

pasuk.text: (Heb. ‘ma’adanoth.’) Jonathan renders: delicately.

text.title: Surely, the bitterness of death has turned.:

pasuk.text: Indeed, I know that the bitterness of death has turned toward me, and is approaching.
to render them veritable widows from their husbands, for you would cut off the membrum virile of the youths of Israel.

(וישסף) He cut him into four pieces. There is no similarity to this word. The Targum renders: ‘ufashah.’ And in our Gemara (i.e., T.B., Bets. 33b) we find: He broke a branch off (‘m’fashah’), and gave us each several sticks, meaning that he split.

(בית-הלחמי,) from Bethlehem, and so is the rule of every noun which is composed of two words, e. g., Beth-lehem, Beth-shemesh, Beth-el, Kiriath-arba, if one wishes to add a ‘heh’ (definite article) thereto, he adds it between the two words, e.g., Kiriath-ha’arba (Gen. 35:27), בית-האלי (I Kings 16:34), בית-הלחמי.
(lit., trembled) hurried out toward him.

text.title: that he said, “Surely, before the Lord is His anointed.”:

pasuk.text: and he said to himself, “Surely, it is true that this one is fitting for the kingdom.”
upon the beauty of his form.
because he is an irascible person, as it is stated: “And Eliab’s wrath was kindled against David” (infra 17:29).

text.title: for it is not as man sees:

pasuk.text: Even though you called yourself ‘seer,’ for you said to Saul, “I am the seer,” (supra 9:19), here I inform you that you do not see.
That is Shimeah (mentioned in II Sam. 12:3; II Chron. 2:13).
(Heb. שאר, kal conj. active) This is like נשאר (remains, niph’al conj. passive).
(לא נסב) We will not sit down to eat. Every instance of sitting down to a meal is called הסבה (leaning).

text.title: And a spirit of the Lord passed:

pasuk.text: a spirit of valiance.
Behold, your servants are before you, who will do your bidding.
The special one of the young men, Doeg the Edomite.
With his entire essence, he intended to introduce Saul’s evil eye into David, i.e., that he envy him.
This is the name of the place.
A hero who would emerge from his battle array, to stand between the two arrays.
scales like those of fish, made of iron, spread over the coat (another version, the holes of the coat), a scale for each hole.
a sort of copper handle, extending from the helmet, opposite the nose, called ‘nasal’ in French, and it reached the feet.
Jonathan renders: ומסחפא דנחשא נפיק מן קולסא ומטל בין כתפוהי A sort of copper javelin, protruding from the helmet, and extending between his shoulders, to protect his neck from the sword.
like a weaver’s beam - (Jonathan) ‘ensouple’ in French (cylinder in a loom).
All shekels mentioned in the Prophetic books, are ‘maneh’s’.
i.e., Why should all of you come out to wage war? Let one fight against me for all of you, and on the condition which is specified: if he is able to fight with me, etc.

text.title: Am I not the Philistine, and you the servants of Saul?:

pasuk.text: I am neither a captain over a hundred, nor a captain over a thousand. I am but a Philistine like one of the others, even though I have fought many wars for them. I killed Hophni and Phinehas, and I captured the Ark. You, on the other hand, have become servants to Saul, although he never saved you with his heroism.
(ברו לכם. The root is ברר). Hence, it is like בררו לכם, (with two ‘resh’es’).
Saul, and let him come down to me.

text.title: And David was the son of this Ephrathite man:

pasuk.text: Bethlehem is situated in the land of Ephrath.

And that which is stated (in I Chron. 2:15), “Ozem the sixth, David the seventh,” and he states no more, may be reconciled by supposing that one died without children. He was, therefore, not counted there.
counted in the assemblies of the esteemed men.
who had heretofore been in Saul’s palace to play music before him.
would always go to and fro from Saul to his father’s house.
Our Rabbis said: (He did this) in order to prevent them from reciting ‘Shema.’
cheeses (Jonathan).

text.title: to the captain of the thousand:

pasuk.text: I say (that Jesse meant) “to the captain of that thousand to which I belong,” for all the tribes had captains of thousands “according to their thousands” (This last phrase is vague). I have heard, however, that ‘to the captain of the thousand’ refers to Jonathan, concerning whom the Scripture states: “And a thousand were with Jonathan in Gibeah of Benjamin.” (supra 13:3).

text.title: and the tidings of their welfare you shall take:

pasuk.text: And the assurance of their salvation and their welfare you shall take into your ears and your heart, and you shall relate it to me. And so did Jonathan render: ‘and their welfare.’

(Heb. ‘arubatham,’) an expression of salvation, like (Ps. 119:112).“Assure your servant for good,” ‘garantir’ in French. Our Rabbis said: He should take a bill of divorcement from them, and deliver it to their wives, to break the connection between man and wife (lit., between him and her).

They would form a circle around the camp, and whoever would go out of the circle, either ahead of or behind the camp, would be liable (to death); ahead, lest the men of the enemy armies attack him, and behind, since he seeks to desert.
(The feminine form is used, referring to) the army of Israel, (which is grammatically feminine).
of the soldiers.

text.title: from the ranks of the Philistines:

pasuk.text: The ‘kethib’ is ממערות פלשתים. Our Rabbis expounded the word מערות : as ממאה ערלות (from 100 foreskins) meaning that one hundred men were intimate (הערו) with his mother Orpah, when she parted with Ruth and her mother-in-law Naomi.

text.title: and he will make his father’s house free:

pasuk.text: from the things mentioned in the laws of the kingdom.
and also a bear (Jonathan).

text.title: Both the lion and the bear:

pasuk.text: These three words (גם את גם) are of inclusive nature, meaning a lion and its two whelps, and a bear and its two cubs.

text.title: The Lord Who saved me from the paw of the lion:

pasuk.text: I know that this incident did not occur to me for naught, but as an indication that in the future, I would come through similar circumstances, to a salvation for Israel. And I shall rely upon this, and go out. And he was one of the two righteous men, to whom the Almighty gave a hint, and they took heed, to understand the matter, viz., David and Mordecai, as it is stated: “And everyday, Mordecai would walk before the courtyard, etc.” (Es. 2:11) He said, “It is not for nothing that this righteous woman (Esther) has been taken into the bed of this uncircumcised one (Ahasuerus). It can only mean that she is destined to stand up for the Jews in a day of distress.”

They changed to David’s size, (explaining מדיו from מדה, a measure, cf., Lev. 6:3) since he had been anointed with the anointing oil, although they belonged to Saul who was taller than any of the people, from his shoulder and upward (supra 9:2), and when Saul noticed this, he cast an envious glance toward him, and David realized it.

and he did not want to go (in them - Jonathan.) (Despite the fact that ויאל usually means, he wanted, [cf., Ex. 2:21],) there are words which have two opposite definitions, e.g., “will cut off a branch (Is. 10:32),” (using מסעף, will cut off, derived from סעיף, a branch). And he will uproot you from the land of the living (Ps 52:7), (using ושרשך, will uproot you, derived from שרש, a root). כי לא נסה for he was not accustomed (after Jonathan).

(Heb. לא נסיתי (Jonathan explains this as derived from נס, a miracle, and, therefore, renders:) for there is no miracle in them, i.e., there will be no praise for the miracle in this manner. Another explanation is ויאל ללכת - he wanted to go, and to try, when he saw that they were too heavy for him, he took them off.
five thin, smooth stones.
(Jonathan renders:) ובתרמיליה.

text.title: and to the cattle of the field:

pasuk.text: It is not customary for cattle to eat human (sic) flesh. Said David “This one’s mind is already deranged (like one who is close to death). He is mine.” David then came and said “… and I shall give the carcasses of the camp of the Philistines… and to the beasts of the earth (not to the cattle).”

text.title: and he fell on his face to the ground:

pasuk.text: He should have fallen backwards since he had been struck in the forehead. But, (he fell forward) in order that David should not be troubled to walk and sever his head, for David saved twelve cubits and two spans. Since his height was six cubits and a span, David saved (a walk of) his entire height back and his entire height forth.
(מדלק) Same as מרדף, similar to “you have pursued me” (דלקת) (Gen. 31: 36).

Our Rabbis said: Did he not recognize him? Is it not stated: “And he became his weapon bearer” (supra 16:21)? But, (rather this is the explanation): he saw him behaving in a kingly manner. (Vid. supra v. 38) Said Saul, “If he comes from the family of Perez, he will be a king, for the king may break fences (פורץ, related to פרץ) to make a way for himself, and no one may stop him. If, however, he comes from the family of Zerah, he will merely become an esteemed person. Said Doeg to him, ” Before you ask whether or not he is descended from a family which qualifies him for the throne, ask whether or not he is qualified to enter the congregation, (i.e., whether or not he may marry among Jews) since he is descended from Ruth the Moabitess.“ Said Abner to him, ” We have learned: An Ammonite (is forbidden, Deut. 23:3) but not an Ammonitess. (Similarly, a Moabite is forbidden, but not a Moabitess.) “ Said Doeg to him, ” If so (let us say), a ‘mamzer’ (the male issue of a union forbidden under penalty of extinction is forbidden,) and not a ‘mamzereth’ (the female issue of such a union).“ He replied, ” It is stated here: Because they did not meet you with bread and water (v. 5 ibid.), and it is not customary for a woman to do so.“ He said to him,” Men should have met men, and women should have met women." Abner became silent. Saul said to him:

text.title: You ask whose son this youth is:

pasuk.text: Above (v. 55) it is written: הנער, and here it is written העלם. He said to him, “This law has escaped your memory (נתעלמה). Go out and ask in the academy.” This is as it is stated in Jeb. 77a.
(ובשלשים) - Jonathan renders: and with cymbals, a type of musical instrument.

text.title: “… And what more can he have…”:

pasuk.text: (lit., and he has yet; i.e.,) What more is he lacking, that he needs to acquire…
He needs nothing else but the kingdom.
with an envious glance.
(lit., he prophesied. Jonathan renders:) and he raved. A prophet and a mad man speak with unintelligible hints.

text.title: “I shall pin David to the wall,”:

pasuk.text: (lit., I shall strike David and the wall) I shall strike one blow that the spear will pierce David and the wall.
to himself (lit., in his heart).

text.title: Let not my hand be upon him:

pasuk.text: lest I be punished.

text.title: but let the hand of the Philistines be upon him.:

pasuk.text: Therefore, he said to him, ‘… and wage the wars of the Lord.’

text.title: at the time that Merab, Saul’s daughter, should have been given:

pasuk.text: When the time which they had set to give her to him arrived, and while they were occupied with giving her to him, the matter turned out that she was given to Adriel.

text.title: With two, shall you become my son-in-law:

pasuk.text: I have two daughters. Through one of them, will you become my son-in-law. And so did Jonathan render: with one of two. Similar to this, (we find:) Three things I cast upon you (II Sam. 24:12), meaning, one of three things. As it is explained there, “Choose for yourself one of them.”

text.title: and the days had not expired:

pasuk.text: He did not wait until the expiration of the days which he had set for him to bring the hundred foreskins.

text.title: and they delivered them in full:

pasuk.text: Presenter in French (to present).
(לרא), equivalent to ליראה (to fear).

text.title: And the princes of the Philistines came out:

pasuk.text: to come in troops to plunder the Israelites.
(lit., at the hand of my father.) Near my father, ‘en son aise’ (‘on his side,’ from Latin ‘adiacentia,’ adjacent) in Old French.
since the teraphim has no hair, and this resembles human hair.
so that they should not understand that he fled, and pursue him.
made in the likeness of a human body.
A hide skinned in one piece, like a skin bottle. Flocete in French (a hairy stuff).

text.title: He said to me, ‘Let me go, etc.’:

pasuk.text: You delivered me into the hands of a bandit. He drew his sword over me until I allowed him to leave.
(lit., dwellings; Jonathan renders:) in the house of study.
להקת, reversed from קהלת a company (Jonathan).

text.title: And he too stripped off his clothes:

pasuk.text: his royal garments, to don the garments of the disciples.

(Rashi’s commentary, as it appears in available editions, is very difficult, and probably erroneous. I should like to take the liberty to emend the text to read:) And he fell naked. Jonathan renders: ונפל ברשן, and in the name of Rabbi Menahem, who heard from an Arab, ברשן in Arabic means insane.

text.title: there is but a step between me and death:

pasuk.text: With (or about) one step I drew away from before him, and he drove the spear into the wall. With that step, I was saved from death.

text.title: Behold tomorrow is the new moon:

pasuk.text: (Heb. ‘hodesh,’ from ‘hadash,’ new.) The renewal of the moon. And of all those who eat at the King’s table, no one refrains from coming to the repast on the festive day.

text.title: and I am accustomed to eat with the king:

pasuk.text: (ואנכי ישב אשב) This is the present tense meaning ‘and I am accustomed to sit with the king regularly to eat beside him.’

text.title: And you shall let me go:

pasuk.text: from now, and I shall hide until the evening of the third day, and I shall not be with the eaters and my seat will be vacant, and the king will wonder about me either tomorrow or the day after tomorrow.
(lit., asked) He asked me for permission.
from year to year at this time.
i.e., he is not angry.

text.title: then it is well with your bondsman:

pasuk.text: He does not have in mind to kill me.
This is proof that he wants me to be accessible to him to kill me.

text.title: the evil has been decided upon by him:

pasuk.text: (lit., the evil has been ended from him) - The end of the matter is, that he has an evil thought concerning me.
to let me go.
to suspect me thus, that I should know that evil has been decided upon by him, and not reveal it to you.
in the place where I shall be hidden?
This is an expression of an oath.
of the following day. That means the third day at this time, for tomorrow is the new moon, and perhaps my father will not wonder (about your absence) tomorrow, but will wonder on the third day.
the Holy One, Blessed be He. (This is an obvious error, and should read:)

text.title: So shall the Lord do to Jonathan.:

pasuk.text: When I sound out my father and find that he is favorable toward you if I do not send by way of messenger and reveal to you, for good I am able to reveal. And if it pleases my father to do evil to you, that I shall not reveal (by messenger), lest your whereabouts become known to my father, but I myself, shall reveal it to you.

text.title: And please, if I am still alive.:

pasuk.text: (ולא אם עודני חי) An expression of request, like ולא and if only it will be given to your bondsman (II Kings 5:17). It is, however, not removed from its usual sense, i.e., “and will you not do with me the kindness of the Lord before I die?” And what is the kindness? That you will not discontinue your kindness with my household. Regarding this, you shall make a covenant with me in my lifetime.

text.title: and not even when the Lord cuts off:

pasuk.text: And also, you shall not remove your kindness from them (מהם) even when retribution befalls my father’s house, for I know that the Lord will cut off your enemies.
this covenant.

text.title: from the hand of David’s enemies:

pasuk.text: The Scripture euphemized. Its real meaning is: The Holy One, Blessed be He, demanded the punishment of the transgression from David’s hand. When he transgressed the covenant, and said to Mephibosheth, “You and Ziba shall divide the field” (II Sam. 19:30), a bath-kol came forth, and said, “Rehoboam and Jeroboam shall divide the kingdom.” And so did Jonathan render: and the Lord took retribution from David’s enemies.
and it is the custom of all those who eat at the king’s table to come on the festive day to the table.
My father will remember you, and ask where you are.

text.title: for your seat will be vacant:

pasuk.text: for your seat in which you sit, will be vacant, and so did Jonathan render: and you will be sought, for your seat will be vacant.
[ונפקדת is] an expression of remembering.
[יפקד is] an expression of lacking.

text.title: And for three days you shall hide very well:

pasuk.text: And you shall triple the days, and then you shall descend very much, i.e., when the third day arrives, you shall descend into a secret place, and hide very well, for then they will seek you. And you shall come to this secret place, wherein you are hiding today, which is a workday. And so did Jonathan render: on the weekday, for he hid on that day, as it is stated: (infra v. 24) “And David hid in the field;” immediately, “and it was the new moon” on the morrow.
(Heb. ‘even-ha azel,’ lit., the going stone, i.e.) a stone which was a sign (a landmark) for travelers.
those who go on the road. And so did Jonathan render: even atha, the stone which was a sign.

text.title: to the side, I shall shoot:

pasuk.text: This is not a ‘mappiq-heh’ (aspirate ‘heh’). צדה is to be interpreted like לצד, to a side, for every word which requires a ‘lamed’ as a prefix, the Scripture gives a ‘he’ as a suffix. (Jeb. 13b) At the side of that stone, I shall shoot arrows to a mark, so that the youth will not understand, and this sign shall be for you to divine whether you must flee.

text.title: And behold, I shall send, etc.:

pasuk.text: And it is customary for one who seeks an arrow which has been shot, to go to the place where he sees the arrow flying, but he cannot ascertain exactly. Sometimes he searches for it, and the arrow is beyond him, and sometimes he goes beyond the arrow and searches for it, and you shall have this sign.

text.title: If I say to the youth… take it and come:

pasuk.text: you yourself emerge from your hiding place, and take it, and come to me, for you have not to fear, for it is well with you. The Holy One Blessed be He, desires that you be here, and even if I have heard evil from Father.

text.title: But, if I say thus… Go! For the Lord has sent you away:

pasuk.text: The Holy One Blessed be He tells you to flee and escape.

text.title: And concerning the matter which we have spoken:

pasuk.text: the covenant which we made together.

text.title: behold, the Lord is between me and you:

pasuk.text: as Witness concerning that matter.
at the head of the couch beside the wall.

He got up from his place, since it is not proper for a son to recline beside his father. Since their custom was to eat reclining on couches and David would recline between Jonathan and Saul, now that David did not come, Jonathan did not recline until Abner sat down beside Saul, and afterwards, Jonathan sat beside Abner. And if you say that he did not sit at all, the Scripture states: (infra v. 34) “And Jonathan arose from the table,” implying that he had been sitting.
He has experienced a seminal emission.
