and he has not yet immersed himself, for had he immersed himself for the uncleanness of his emission, he would not have to wait until sunset in order to eat ordinary food.
This clause gives the reason for the matter; i.e., since he is not clean, he, therefore, did not come, lest he contaminate the feast.

text.title: on the morrow of the new moon:

pasuk.text: on the morrow of the renewal of the moon.
on the second day of the month.

text.title: and he, my brother, commanded me:

pasuk.text: The eldest of the house, commanded me that I be there. And he is my brother Eliab.
‘Escamoter’ in French. I shall go away for one day and come back.

text.title: a straying woman, deserving of punishment:

pasuk.text: (בן נעות המרדות) An expression of straying and wandering, נע ונד, a gadding woman. Just as you say זעוה from זע, and the ‘tav’ is for the construct state, for it is connected to the word המרדות.

(Heb. המרדות), who deserves to be chastised and disciplined. Another explanation is as follows: When the men of Benjamin grabbed the girls of Shiloh, who came out to dance in the vineyards (Jud. 21:21), Saul was bashful, and did not want to grab [a girl], until she came herself, behaving insolently, and pursued him. נעות because of the vineyards. And that is a winepress, like (the Talmudical passage): Purge the winepress (which was used for forbidden wine) (Ab. Zarah 74b); His winepresses will drip with wine (Targum Onkelos, Gen. 40:12)….(The last three words of Rashi are incomprehensible, and are probably erroneous. The correct version is unknown to us.)
concerning David.

text.title: for his father had put him to shame:

pasuk.text: concerning David.
at the time which David had set for him.

text.title: to cause it to go beyond him.:

pasuk.text: The arrow went beyond the boy.

text.title: from a place toward the south:

pasuk.text: (lit., from by the south. Jonathan renders:) from the side of the travelers’ (or sign) stone which was toward the south.
He cried more.
And the oath which we have sworn, may the Lord be witness thereon forever.

text.title: And I troubled the young men:

pasuk.text: (Heb. ‘va’yada’) An expression of troubling. The young men who came out with me, I have troubled them to run before me to a hidden, secret place.
similar to, “And with them he broke (va’yoda) the men of Succoth” (Jud. 8:16).
(Heb. ‘ploni almoni.’) ‘Almoni’ is derived from ‘almon’ (a widower), bereft of a name, (as a widower is bereft of his spouse), for I do not wish to mention it, since it is a secret matter.
(Heb. ‘ploni,’) like: ‘ki yipalei’ (Deut. 17:8), which means ‘will be concealed.’
If there are not five, give me whatever is found in your possession.
With difficulty, I give them to strangers (non-priests) to eat, but it is impossible to give it to unclean people.
lit., withheld to us.

text.title: and the young men’s garments are hallowed:

pasuk.text: i.e., ritually clean.

text.title: and that is in a manner common:

pasuk.text: and the bread, since it has been removed from the table, and they have burned the spoonfuls (of frankincense), it is almost common, since it has been excluded from the prohibition of ‘me’ilah’ (betrayal) from the time it is permitted for the priests.

text.title: and even if today it would be hallowed in the vessel:

pasuk.text: and even if today were the commencement of its sanctity on the table, I should (or perhaps it should read, ‘you would’) be obliged to take it from there and feed us, for a ravenous hunger has seized me, and my life is in danger. Thus it is explained in Men. (95b).
i. e., other warm bread on the day this was taken away. And our Rabbis said: Warm on the day it was taken - It was as warm on the day it was taken as it was on the day it was arranged.
he tarried before the tent of meeting to engage in Torah.
the head of the tribunal.
And if there is here.
hurried.
(Heb (לוטה wrapped, and so: “and be wrapped (וילט) his face in his mantle” (I Kings 19:13).
(after the ephod) after he had consulted the Urim and Tummim for him. And so did Jonathan render: after he asked the ephod for him.

text.title: Is this not David the king of the land?:

pasuk.text: They said to Achish, There was a stipulation between us, (supra 17:9) “If he is able to fight with me and kill me, we shall be slaves to you.” You have nothing to do but get off your throne and let him become king of this land.
his speech. ויתהולל and he feigned insanity.
he wrote.
(Heb. ‘riro’) his saliva. Anything which drips is called ‘rir,’ and so: “in saliva (b’rir) of health” (Job 6:7), and so: “whether his flesh run (rar)” (Lev. 15:3).
(הזה)
This is a question form. It is therefore punctuated by a “hataf patah” (under the ‘heh’), and (the ‘zain’) is not punctuated by a ‘dagesh.’

text.title: and they stayed with him all the time that David was in the stronghold:

pasuk.text: near Moab, and when David went away from there to the forest of Heresh, the king of Moab slew his father, mother, and brothers, with the exception of one of them, whom Nahash the Ammonite preserved alive. And that is the kindness which David (meant when he) said, (II Sam. 10:2) “As his father did kindness with me,” as it is stated in the Mid. of Rabbi T. (T. Buber, Vayera 25).
for he investigated, to beware of him.

text.title: under the tamarisk tree on a hill:

pasuk.text: (Heb. ‘b’ramah,’) on one hill, which was in the border of Benjamin. Our Rabbis, however, said: This was Samuel’s Ramah, and since these are two distinct places, it is expounded thus: Saul was sitting in Gibeah through the merit of the great tamarisk tree (Samuel) who was in Ramah, and was praying for him.

text.title: and by inquiring of the Lord on his behalf:

pasuk.text: You made him a king (by inquiring of the Urim and Tummim for him), since we may not inquire of the Urim and Tummim for a commoner.

text.title: and goes to do your service:

pasuk.text: (וסר) like “And they turned to him (ויסורו)” (Gen. 19:6), meaning that he comes near to do your service and to do your commands. (The root סור, which usually means ‘to turn away,’ is used here to mean ‘to come near.’) Was I able to understand that he was not going on your mission?

text.title: Have I begun today to inquire:

pasuk.text: This is a question, inferring as follows: It is already a long time that the community has need for him for he (i.e., the king) appointed him as the one who leads Israel to and from battle, and since then, I inquire of God on his behalf.
to have done this thing with the intent of rebellion or treason.
They were Abner and Amassa.

They expounded ‘buts’ and ‘onlys.’ The Scripture states: “Every man who rebels against your command shall be put to death” (Jos. 1:18). One may think that this means even to commit a sin. The Scripture, therefore, states: Only (be strong and of good courage).
(the ‘kethib’ is דויג, upon which our Rabbis comment:) His name was changed (from דואג to דויג). He said to him, “You are caught like a fish. You informed on them. You slay them.”
I brought about the matter until it came to this.

text.title: for he who seeks my soul:

pasuk.text: One man is pursuing both of us. Wherever I shall escape, you shall escape, for you will always be in my safeguard. Jonathan renders: for he who seeks to kill me, seeks to kill you. It may also be interpreted: for he who will love me, will love you, and he who will guard my soul, will guard your soul. There is another instance of this in the Scriptures: “Men of blood hate him that is sincere, but the upright seek his soul” (Prov. 29:10). Here is (an instance of) seeking a soul for good.

text.title: God has delivered him into my hand:

pasuk.text: (נכר) delivered, and so, “And do not look on, on the day of your brother, on the day of his being delivered” (Ob. 1:12). This is the conjugation of the strong verbs (piel, being punctuated by a dagesh in the middle letter of the root), like בריחיה אבד ושבר“He destroyed and broke her bars” (Lam. 21:9). (These words are punctuated in like manner.) If he desired to speak in the conjugation of the weak verbs, (Kal), it would have been punctuated thus: נכר.

text.title: for he has been shut in by coming into a city with doors and bars:

pasuk.text: and he will rely on that, and will not take care to flee from me.
plotting the evil (from Jonathan).

text.title: Will the citizens of Keilah deliver me:

pasuk.text: We derive from here that one who inquires concerning two matters, receives a reply concerning one only, and he is only answered concerning the first one. And here, David asked in an inverted order, since he should have first asked, Will Saul come down? Will the citizens of Keilah deliver me? He was answered according to the order (in which he should have asked).
(Jonathan renders:) in a place where it is proper to go, in a place where they would be saved.
He renewed the covenant which was between them.
and it is incumbent upon us to deliver him.
(lit., for he told me.) The one who told.
He acts with cunning; today he is here and tomorrow in another place, so that no one should know where he is.
with an exact and true statement.
for Saul was destined to go after them, and they went before him, to search (and find out) exactly (where David was).
(עטרים, from עטרה, a crown;) i.e., encircling and surrounding from side to side, like a crown which encircles the head.
(Heb. ‘malach’) a real angel, in order to save David.
that Saul’s heart was divided by two thoughts, whether to return to save his country from the Philistines, or to pursue David. Thus Jonathan renders.
the Rocks of the Wild Goats.
To stool.

text.title: And he said to his men,:

pasuk.text: “The Lord forbid…” These two verses are written in reversed order, but since he began to speak of the severing of the coat, he finished all the matter concerning it, and stated that he even regretted the severing of the coat. Afterwards, he returns to his first subject, and states that upon his men’s statement, “Behold, concerning this day, etc.” He retorted to them, “May the Lord forbid it for me, etc.”
He separated and held them off with these words.
Why should you accept Doeg’s slander concerning me?

text.title: and (one) said to kill you, but (my soul) had pity on you:

pasuk.text: (lit., and said to kill you, and she had pity on you) Two words are missing here, (to be explained thus): and the sayer said that I should kill you, but my soul had pity on you, similar to “and David longed to go forth to Absalom” (II Sam. 14:2. In our editions, it is 13:39), (meaning): and the soul of David longed.
i.e., pay attention to the matter, and also see the testimony, for the skirt of your coat is in my hand, and I was able to kill you.

text.title: As says the proverb of the ancient one:

pasuk.text: the proverb of the Ancient One of the world; i.e., the Torah, which is the proverb of the Holy One Blessed be He.

text.title: “From the wicked one comes forth wickedness”:

pasuk.text: The Holy One Blessed be He, destines the wicked to fall into the hand of another wicked man like himself. And where did the Torah say (this)?“And the Lord destined it into his hand” (Ex. 21:13), as it is stated in Tractate Makkoth (10b).

text.title: I know that you will reign:

pasuk.text: for I see that the Holy One blessed be He saves you from my hand. The Midrash Agadah states: Samuel transmitted this sign to him that the one who tears his coat will reign after him.
the name of the city.
(lit., his work, or deed.) His cattle and his possessions.
wealthy.

text.title: and he was, while shearing his sheep, in Carmel:

pasuk.text: And he was one day, when the time of his sheepshearing came around, in Carmel. And his custom was to make a banquet and a festival for the sheepshearers.
of the house of Caleb.
will he be shearing in the coming year. (
So shall be next year living and existing luck.) (Another version is:

Say this concerning his meal and his wine, “So is befitting a live man, and active and esteemed man,” like: [II Sam. 23:20] “the son of a live man (kethib) of many heroic deeds.” I.e., alive and active in all his deeds.)
good and existing.
So shall it be to the length of days.
If they needed us for anything, we did not send them back empty handed.

text.title: neither was anything missing to them.:

pasuk.text: of your flocks, for we were watching for them.
i.e., my youths, find favor in your eyes, for the kindness which your servants will tell concerning them.

text.title: for we have come on a festive day.:

pasuk.text: Depending upon the banquet and festive day which you have, we have now come to ask. Another explanation is: This was the eve of Rosh Hashanah, (and they said,) “We are in need of a holiday feast.”

text.title: and spoke to Nabal according to all these words, in David’s name, and they rested:

pasuk.text: They were weary from the way, yet they were quick to execute David’s command, and did not rest until they spoke to him, and afterwards they rested. Jonathan, however, renders: and they ceased, i.e., they stopped speaking further, until they would hear his reply.
Of what importance is he that I should give him mine? Is he not descended from Ruth the Moabitess?

text.title: and David too, girded his sword:

pasuk.text: Hence, we derive that in cases involving capital punishment, we commence from the most insignificant in law first.
to watch their tents and utensils.
hers.
(ויעט בהם) With words, he made them fly away. An expression of עיט (a bird) (Gen. 15:11).
(Heb. הכלמנו ולא. This is synonymous with the usual passive form,) ולא נכלמנו.

text.title: for the evil has been decided upon:

pasuk.text: by David against him.

text.title: and he is such a base person that I cannot speak to him:

pasuk.text: And our master is such a base person that I cannot speak to him that which I am saying to you, lest he become angry with us.

Jonathan renders: תכברא, filled with finely cut meat and eggs. Pates (meat pies) in French, as we learned in Pesahim (74a): And he places the feet and its intestines inside. Rabbi Tarfon calls it תכברא, (a combination of two words, תוך, inside, and ברא, outside). That which is inside is placed outside, according to Rabbi Akiva, who says that the intestines hang outside of it (the paschal lamb). Thus it is stated in the Tosefta(?), and Rabbi Klonimos of sainted memory, from Rome, explained it to us thusly.
dried grapes.
round cakes of dried figs, trodden and pressed in a vessel.
There was a valley between the two mountains. She was going down one mountain, and they were going down the opposite mountain.
to himself when his youths related to him Nabal’s insults, “Surely in vain have I watched, etc.”

(משתין בקיר.) Jonathan renders: one possessing intelligence, (explaining משתין from משית, placing, i.e.,) one who places the walls of his heart (i.e., capable of intelligent thought, an adult). Another explanation is: even a dog whose manner is to urinate against the wall, (explaining משתין in the usual manner).

text.title: In me alone, my lord, is the iniquity:

pasuk.text: First she said this so that he would heed her words. At the end, however, she told him the truth: “I, your handmaid, did not see my lord’s youths” (supra v. 25).
for He sent me toward you to withhold you from bloodshed.

text.title: and from saving yourself with your hand:

pasuk.text: lest you personally avenge yourself and be punished.
She prophesied with the divine spirit that Nabal would not live long.
(Heb. ונתנה)And it shall be given to the youths, etc. נתנה, (It was given) is past tense, ונתנה (with a ‘vav’) is future tense.

text.title: for the Lord shall make for my lord a sure house:

pasuk.text: to be King over Israel. Therefore,

text.title: let no evil be found in you:

pasuk.text: Therefore, it is not fitting for you to do anything contrary to the Law, to spread evil talk concerning your kingdom.

text.title: the soul of your enemies, the Lord will sling it with the hollow of the sling:

pasuk.text: A wide piece of leather, made like a sort of hollow, in the middle of the sling, in which one places the stone.

text.title: And it will be, when the Lord will do, etc.:

pasuk.text: and you will reign.

text.title: And let this not be to you as a stumbling block:

pasuk.text: (לפוקה) as a stumbling block, like: “and the stumbling (ופיק) of the knees” (Nahum 2:11), for, had you done this, you would not be able to open your mouth to reprove anyone of the future generations, concerning bloodshed.

text.title: or that my lord has avenged himself:

pasuk.text: that you avenge yourself.
(Heb. כליתני) you withheld me, like: You shall not withhold (תכלא) your mercy (Ps. 40:12); will not withhold (כלה) from you (Gen. 12:7).

text.title: and from avenging myself with my own hand:

pasuk.text: (lit., and avenging etc.) This is connected with the phrase, “from coming into bloodshed.” The ‘mem’ of מבוא, (from coming) is connected to ‘and avenging,’ to be explained as, ‘from coming into bloodshed and from avenging myself with my own hand.’

text.title: when the wine had left Nabal:

pasuk.text: when the effect of the wine had left Nabal (from Jonathan).
(He became paralyzed and lifeless, because) he was shocked concerning the gift which had been brought to David.

The Holy One Blessed be He suspended his sentence until after Samuel’s mourning period, lest the mourning period of this wicked man coincide with his mourning period. Afterward, He reprieved him for three days and he died, as it is stated: And the Lord inflicted a stroke upon Nabal, and the Rabbi said: If one was ill three days and died, this is a death of a stroke (or a plague). Our Rabbis stated: These are the Ten Days of Repentance (between Rosh Hashanah and Yom Kippur, cf. supra v. 8) which the Holy One Blessed be He waited for him to repent. Some say that they correspond to the meals which Nabal gave David’s servants for David had sent him ten youths (supra v. 5), and he fed them (v. 9“and they rested” meaning that he gave them refreshments).
my insult which he insulted me today, (by saying, Who is David and who is the son of Jesse?). Nowadays there are many slaves who break away (supra v. 10).

text.title: and restrained His bondsman from evil:

pasuk.text: that I did not kill him.
thrust (lit., crushed).
Some say: He swore to his temptation. While others say: He swore to Abishai: If you kill this righteous man, I shall mingle your blood with his blood.

text.title: but the Lord will smite him:

pasuk.text: will bring his death prematurely.
the day in which his death is destined.
jug.
(Heb. הסיתך בי) to hate me. Every expression of הסתה means setting, (setting one against another), ameutement in French, (inciting, stirring up).
(lit., will smell an offering,) will accept with mercy my prayer to turn your anger away from me.
from Eretz Israel.

One who goes out of Eretz Israel to other lands (during the existence of the Temple [probably inserted by the censors]) is accounted as though he worshipped idols. Jonathan, however, paraphrases: Go, David, among nations who worship idols.

(Heb. ‘hakoray’) a bird named ‘koray’ and in French ‘perdrix’ (partridge), and so: (Jer. 17:11) “As the partridge which hatches the eggs which she has not laid. And it hunts after the nests of other birds and sits on them.”
(lit., to the man) to every righteous man.

text.title: Now, I shall perish one day:

pasuk.text: Perhaps he will ambush me and come upon me suddenly.

text.title: for why should your servant dwell, etc.:

pasuk.text: and be a burden to you?

The minimum of days, being two. It is impossible to explain this word, ‘yomim,’ as ‘a year,’ since David did not go to Achish until Samuel had died, and Saul reigned only four months after Samuel’s demise, as we learned in S.O. (ch. 13). (This can) also (be determined) from the number of Eli’s years (i.e., the forty years which he judged Israel, supra 4:18), and the twenty years that the Ark was in Kiriath-jearim (supra 7:2), totaling sixty years. Subtract therefrom Samuel’s fifty-two years, plus one year for his conception with these four months, plus the seven years which David reigned in Hebron (II Sam. 5:5) before he brought the Ark from Kiriath-jearim. It is found that Saul reigned after Samuel’s demise but four months.
This is a present tense. He was always accustomed to this.
from the entrance of Shur (according to Rashi’s version of Jonathan).
(Heb. אל פשטתם) The ‘lamed’ is substituted for a ‘nun’ (making the word אן, where) like: And he made for himself a chamber (נשכה) in the book of Ezra (Neh. 13:7) like לשכה.

It was already stated: And Samuel died (supra 25:1), but since he came to speak of Saul, that he had to ask of a necromanceress, he commenced by saying: And Samuel had died, for had he been alive, Saul would have inquired of him. And since Saul had abolished the necromancers, he had to seek a necromanceress.

text.title: and all Israel lamented him and buried him in Ramah, and… in his own city.:

pasuk.text: (The difficulty of the word ‘and’ is explained by Jonathan with the following paraphrase:) And all Israel lamented him and buried him in Ramah, and each one lamented him in his own city. ‘And in his city’ is connected with ‘And they lamented him.’ They lamented him and buried him in Ramah, and each one lamented him in his own city.
Since he had slain Nob, the priestly city, he was not answered.

(ויתחפש) , he changed his clothes and similarly, “Disguise yourself and come into the battle” (I Kings 22:30). And similarly, “By the great force (of my disease), is my garment changed” (Job 30:18). And so did Jonathan render: And Saul changed.

text.title: and they came to the woman by night:

pasuk.text: It was (really) daytime but because of their distress it seemed to them (dark) as night. So did Rabbi Tanhuma expound (this passage).
seek a stumbling block.

for she saw him ascending not in the usual manner of those who ascend through necromancy, for when one conjures up (the dead) through necromancy, they ascend with their feet upward, while this one was ascending with his head upward, in honor of Saul.

text.title: I have seen angels ascending from the earth.:

pasuk.text: Two angels (righteous men as holy as angels), viz., Moses and Samuel, for Samuel feared, “Perhaps I am being summoned for judgment,” and brought Moses up with him, as it is stated in Hag. 4b (and in Taan.).

Three things were said concerning necromancy, viz., (1) The one who conjures him (the dead) up sees him, but does not hear his voice. (2) The one who inquires of him hears him, but does not see him. Therefore, he asked, ‘What is his form?’ (3) Others neither see nor hear him.

text.title: and he is wrapped in a cloak:

pasuk.text: for he was accustomed to wear a cloak, as it is stated: And his mother would make him a small cloak (supra 2:19). He was buried with it, and so he arose. And so in the future, will the dead rise with their garments.
You have caused me to shudder.

text.title: neither through the prophets nor through dreams:

pasuk.text: But he did not tell him of the Urim and Tummim, even though he had inquired of them, as it is stated above (v. 6), for he was ashamed of it, since he had slain Nob the priestly city.

(ואקראה) An expression meaning: And I have been summoned after you, similar to: I was summoned (נקרא נקראתי) on Mt. Gilboa (II Sam. 1:6), and similar to: “And there chanced an unscrupulous man” (II Sam. 20:1). (The reference is ambiguous.) It was necessary for me to be summoned after you, that you let me know what I am to do.

text.title: And why do you ask me:

pasuk.text: Since you have asked of the live prophets.
(Jonathan paraphrases) and has become the supporter of the man whose adversary you are.

(Heb. ‘orecha,’) an expression meaning an enemy. There are many (examples) in the Scriptures, e. g.: “And they will fill the face of the earth with adversaries” (Is. 14:21); “And I shall destroy your adversaries” (Mic. 5:13); “The dream be to your enemies and its interpretation to your adversaries” (Dan. 3:49. In our editions 4:16, Christian editions 4:19).

But during his lifetime, he did not mention his name to him, only “and gave it to your fellow who is better than you” (supra 15:28) because he feared him lest he kill him, since he (Samuel) had anointed him (David) as king.

text.title: you and your sons will be with me:

pasuk.text: in my abode.
a fatted calf (from Jonathan).
from the day of his camping with me.

text.title: and they came to the Brook Besor:

pasuk.text: six hundred men.

text.title: and those who were left behind stayed:

pasuk.text: When they reached the Brook Besor, there were among them some who were faint, and some of them remained there.
(Heb. (פגרו, who refrained. And I say that this is Aramaic, the translation of ונהרסו (Ez. 30:4) and they will be destroyed.

To the south of the Philistines, for we find elsewhere that the Philistines are called a nation of Cherethites [as it says,] “the inhabitants of the seacoast, the nation of the Cherethites! [The word of the Lord is against you, Canaan land of the Philistines]…” (Zeph. 2:5).
The Amalekites are accustomed to being defeated on the morrow (On the second day of battle), as it is stated (Ex. 17:9): “Tomorrow I shall stand etc.” Therefore, it is stated: on their morrow.

text.title: all the sheep and the cattle:

pasuk.text: which the troop had captured from the south of Judah and from the south of Caleb.
men who were leading and marching before those cattle, to honor and praise themselves, (by saying,) “This is David’s spoil.”

(lit., from that day and above) It is not stated: from that day on, but ‘from that day and above (i.e., before).’ Abraham had already instituted this statute when he said, “Aside from that which the youths have eaten,” those are the ones who stayed with the luggage, “and the share of the men” who went to war.
(לרעהו), to his friends.
for they would hide him from Saul.

text.title: And the Philistines fought with Israel:

pasuk.text: This is like a person saying, “Let us return to the earlier topic.”
(אליו, lit., to him) like עליו, about him, i.e., about Saul.

(Jonathan renders:) And they burned for them as they burn for the kings there. As we learned: (A.Z. 11a, Tos. Sab. ch. 8:9, Tos. San. ch. 4:2) We perform burning at the burial of kings, and it is not considered a custom of the Amorites.
